abstracts.cdata!:
This is a resettlement policy framework
            for the Malawi Education Sector support Project, which
            improves educational quality by increasing the quantity and
            quality of teachers and strengthening government capacity to
            manage the system and financial resources. Social impacts
            are likely to occur during the construction and
            rehabilitation of educational facilities. When
            rehabilitating community day secondary schools, the
            Polytechnic Institute, and the Chancellor College, take care
            during the screening process to identify all possible land
            uses, for example, crop production or grazing at these
            facilities to ensure compensation. No social impacts are
            likely when Mzuzu University is rehabilitated. When building
            the Teacher Training College, social impacts may occur with
            land use changes along with the need to acquire land to
            accommodate building power distribution lines to connect the
            campus to the grid. Regarding the development and use of
            borrow pits as sources of construction materials, potential
            impacts include loss of access to economic activities and
            loss of livelihoods due to the need for land acquisition to
            develop new borrow pits. This report outlines the conditions
            which will determine whether a full or abbreviated
            resettlement action plan is needed, the applicable laws, the
            methods of valuing affected assets, the policy for
            compensation for property and crops, the organizational
            procedures for delivering entitlements, the grievance
            redress mechanisms, budget and funding arrangements, methods
            for community consultation, and monitoring arrangements.
